title: Expressing Needs
description: Explore how safe it feels to express physical and emotional needs

questions.text: I can express what I need physically without fear.

therapeutic.rationale: Expressing physical needs requires courage and safety. Fear of judgment, rejection, or disappointing your partner can silence important communication.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner can't express needs without fear, explore what creates the fear. Building safety for expression takes intentional effort.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual ability to express physical needs creates clarity and connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What physical needs are easy to express? What feels harder to ask for?

questions.text: My partner seems genuinely interested in understanding what I need.

therapeutic.rationale: Genuine interest in understanding—not just hearing—your partner's needs demonstrates care. This interest invites more open sharing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel interest in their needs, explore how curiosity could be shown more clearly.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual genuine interest in each other's needs creates a learning orientation toward intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show interest in understanding your needs?

questions.text: I feel heard when I share what matters to me physically.

therapeutic.rationale: Being heard—really heard, not just acknowledged—about physical needs validates that your experience matters. Feeling unheard leads to silence or resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel heard, explore what 'heard' looks like for them. Sometimes partners hear but don't show it in recognizable ways.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of being heard creates confidence to keep sharing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When have you felt most heard about your physical needs? What made the difference?

questions.text: I'm learning what my partner needs, and that feels good.

therapeutic.rationale: A learning orientation toward your partner's needs—curiosity rather than assumption—keeps intimacy growing. When learning feels good rather than burdensome, connection deepens.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If learning doesn't feel good for one partner, explore why. Is there pressure? Confusion? Criticism when they get it wrong?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual enjoyment of learning about each other creates ongoing discovery in intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What have you learned about your partner's needs? What are you still curious about?

questions.text: There's space in our relationship for both of our needs.

therapeutic.rationale: When both partners' needs have space, neither feels they have to choose between themselves and the relationship. One-sided dynamics breed resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel space for their needs, explore what's taking up the space. Whose needs tend to dominate?
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual sense that both needs have space creates balanced, sustainable intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do both of your needs get attention? What would create more space for yours?
